Award.AwardTitle: MCBIOS Conference on Computational Biology and Bioinformatics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: The MidSouth Computational Biology and Bioinformatics Society (MCBIOS) is a nonprofit organization to promote research and education in bioinformatics and computational biology and address the need for the next generation of scientists who will work at the interface between computational and life sciences. This conference plays a special role in the region, providing a quality research-focused environment, serving as an arm for the international community of scientists in bioinformatics and computational biology. A major purpose of the MCBIOS annual conference is to foster collaborative research in bioinformatics and computational biology by providing a forum for scientists of various backgrounds and disciplines to interact to solve biological, health and/or biomedical problems by developing or using computational tools. The broader impacts of the project will be met through initiating future collaborations by the ensuing discussions of open problems, providing strong support to graduate and undergraduate students and a platform for new researchers to the field. The meeting also includes industry participants, which will provide students with knowledge of various types of employment opportunities and needed skill sets for those opportunities and provides for the publication of the proceedings in BMC Bioinformatics, a high impact factor journal.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The MidSouth Computational Biology and Bioinformatics Society (MCBIOS) is a non-profit organization formed to promote research and education in bioinformatics and computational biology. This organization also addresses the need for the next generation of scientists to work on the interface between computational and life sciences. Since 2004, the MCBIOS conference is held annually and is hosted by various universities throughout the MidSouth region. In this region, the states included are Arkansas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Missouri, Oklahoma, Tennessee and Texas. The National Science Foundation (NSF) Fund was requested to support the 12th annual MCBIOS conference that was held March 12-14, 2015 in Little Rock, Arkansas. This conference addressed various aspects of "Emerging Trends in Bioinformatics". The conference was composed of a strong list of invited speakers, students and special sessions.

A large portion of the NSF fund supports students in their conference registration fees, lodging, and promotion of education (student awards for poster and oral presentations) in bioinformatics and computational biology. We invited two prominent speakers in bioinformatics and computational biology, and encouraged student organizations in public state higher education facilities (as well as students at regional level) to participate. 158 people attended the 2015 MCBIOS conference, including twenty-one post-doctoral individuals and eighty students. 141 abstracts were presented - sixty as oral presentations, and eight-one as poster presentations. Oral presentation sessions were organized by topic into twelve sessions consisting of five presentations each. The NSF fund was used to support two keynote speakers and fifteen graduate students. A meeting of the Regional Student Group (RSG): MidSouthern-US, an affiliate student group of the International Society for Computational Biology, was held at the conference. Five students were recognized for leadership contribution in the previous year.

NSF support is instrumental in the success of the conference. This support allows us to increase participation on every level, to recognize the work of students and post-doctoral members, and to encourage innovation and progress. The intellectual merit of this project is captured by our strong list of invited speakers. These speakers address various aspects of the conference themes. The organization of special sessions whose focus is the most current and cutting-edge topics in the field contributes to the synergy of the researchers in attendance. The broader impacts of this project have been met through the strong support we provide to graduate and undergraduate students. Our efforts include opportunities in the role of industry (computational biology) that provide students with knowledge of various types of employment opportunities and needed skillsets for those opportunities. All papers were peer-reviewed and fifteen significant articles are included in the final proceedings published in the BMC Bioinformatics journal.
